content.description: The holds get a little slopey in the middle but improve towards the top.
Stay to the right of the blunt arete making use of good holds. The lower ledge to the right is off. Tricky moves up high lead to good finish holds.
content.location: Start on the crimpy crack to the right of the tree stub.

content.description: Start on the V0 climbing up to the second crack. Follow the crack right and finish up Beach Trooper.
content.location: Start to the right of the tree close to the rock.

content.description: An easy and fun sit start with your hands on a ledge near the ground brings you to a stand on the ledge. Use good feet and bad hands to work your way up to the top. A small crack becomes a left-hand sidepull, and a good right-hand pinch can be used to top out. A sloppy topout may turn into a beached whale topout.
content.protection: A couple of crash pads, maybe a slide pad, and a spotter.If this problem is near your limit, consider having a spotter place a slide pad on the starting ledge once you are above it.
content.location: Grab the left-facing edge of the ledge near the ground on the south side of the boulder to start. If you end up climbing on the big lichen, you went too far right.

content.description: Somewhat secluded with partial to full shade, this slabby boulder presents multiple technical slab climbs. The top of the boulder is somewhat flat and can be a comfortable place to sit for a small group. There is no downclimb. You can walk down on either side of the hill to get back down, but the hill is steep enough that pine needles tend to slip, so be careful especially if walking on pads on your way down.
